## Exercise 1.1

<!-- @ consider perceived waiting times for the bus. They interviewed public transit users over perceived traffic time and real time for buses lines operating around  Ohio State University in Columbus. Measured waiting times ranged between 3 and 15 minutes. -->

Consider an independent and identically distributed sample from an exponential distribution with rate $\lambda>0$, with associated density $f(x) = \lambda \exp(-\lambda x)$.

Compute the marginal likelihood when the prior for $\lambda$ is 

a. an exponential distribution with rate $\kappa>0$, with prior density $p(\lambda) = \kappa \exp(-\lambda\kappa)$;
b. same, but truncated above at 1, so the density is $p(\lambda) = \kappa \exp(-\lambda\kappa)\mathrm{I}\{\lambda \leq 1\}$; where $\mathrm{I}$ is one if the condition is satisfied and zero otherwise
c. $\lambda \sim \mathsf{Ga}(\alpha, \beta)$, a gamma distribution with shape $\alpha>0$ and rate $\beta>0$, with prior density $p(\lambda) = \beta^\alpha\lambda^{\alpha-1}\exp(-\beta \lambda)/\Gamma(\alpha)$.

Deduce that, in all cases above and up to truncation, the posterior distribution is a gamma distribution.

## Exercise 1.2

We model data using an exponential distribution with rate $\lambda$, and consider the following priors

a. a gamma distribution with rate $\beta=20$ and shape $\alpha = 20$
b. an exponential distribution with unit rate
c. a gamma distribution with rate $\beta=0.1$ and shape $\alpha = 10$
d. a uniform prior on the unit interval [0,1]

Suppose we collect a random sample of size $n=10$, with average value $\overline{y}=1.3$

Associate each plot of the posterior with each of the priors.

Explain what would happen if we increased the sample size.

## Exercice 1.4

Consider a half Cauchy prior over the positive half line, with density $p(\lambda) = 2\pi^{-1}(1+x^2)^{-1}$. Using a grid approximation in increments of 0.1, evaluate the posterior density from 0 until 10 and renormalize. 

Compare this with a numerical approximation of the integral using quadrature methods via `integrate` and return the corresponding normalizing constant.


## Exercice 1.3

Consider a unit exponential prior with the same data, $n=10$ and $\overline{y}$.

1. Return the posterior mean, posterior median and maximum a posteriori (MAP).
2. Return the 89% equi-tailed percentile credible interval.
3. Return the 50% highest posterior density (HPD) interval

Next, draw 100 observations from the posterior predictive distribution and plot a histogram of the latter. Compare it to the exponential distribution of observations.

Would the posterior predictive change if you gathered more data? Justify your answer and explain how it would change, if at all.
